name: Predicting Soccer Matches: A Neural Network Approach
body:
### **Introduction**
Predicting the results of sports is a big deal for many people, ranging from casual fans to analysts and sports franchises. Accurately predicting the scores and outcomes of matches not only is important to fans but also to organizers to create fair leagues. The purpose of this project is to implement various neural network approaches in accurately predicting soccer scores in the English Premier League and testing their accuracy.

### **Problem Description**
Soccer is a highly competitive sport with many factors affecting each game. Given a team dataset, successfully implement and compare different neural networks to accurately predict soccer scores and outcomes using past matches for the EPL and additional features.

![](http://i.imgur.com/d0SFDgS.png)

In the sample data set given, the values of division, Home Team, Away Team, FTHG, FTAG, HS, AS (which are acronyms for different soccer statistics like Full-Time Home Goals, Home shots, etc.) are read into a dictionary. This makes it easier to access a value with some key and extracting the value given the key for the data set.


### **Methods**
The match data was read into a training, validation, and testing sets for classifier algorithms. In the given flow chart below, the raw data from the soccer website was read in and scaled by assigning each value in a dictionary. This was then used to create a training set and validation set to build the experiment. This was done by designating EPL seasons 2000-2009 as the training data set, EPL seasons 2010-2014 as the testing set, and LL seasons 2000-2004 as the validation set. Using statistics from La Liga for the validation set allowed the increase the size of the training set to 10 seasons of EPL data, but considered it best to train a classifier on the same league (EPL) as the testing set.

![Flow Chart](http://i.imgur.com/wZR2NjS.png)

The dictionary values constructed were best suited to machine learning algorithms, and were evaluated with a multinomial naive Bayes classifier, a support vector machine, a perceptron, a stochastic gradient descent model, and a Gaussian naive Bayes classifier

### **Results**

The prediction being tested is whether a game will result in a win, loss, or tie. Also based off historical data, what will be the final score of a match by using various features such as previous games, shots taken on the goal, etc. The neural networks generated match predictions that can be comparable to actual match results. Different algorithms were compared with each other to determine which approach classified the labels correctly. 

![](http://i.imgur.com/kyvD7cZ.png)
![](http://i.imgur.com/IHezn7t.png)
![](http://i.imgur.com/PZgnSH3.png)
![](http://i.imgur.com/vLzUcBv.png)

By generating dictionary values for the data set, the simple last-result approach became the baseline against which was compared more complicated features. These complicated features consisted of: number of past matches considered, changing which features were derived from each game such as shots taken or half-time score, and combining all features.

### **Conclusions**

After much data analysis, I found using less features that the Gaussian Bayes, the Multi Bayes, and SVM were more accurate than the perceptron and SGD. However, comparing features individually seemed to produce lower accuracies than when combining features. Also worth noting is that the best indication of which team is going to win is dependent primarily on head to head games within the last 2 games, as any more produced more noise. Even with that, the classifiers were able to produce higher accuracies than the baseline model of last-result.

Future work will involve using a larger dataset and improving the model by including in the feature vectors the betting odds produced by popular consensus or other predictive algorithms.
